Award.AwardTitle: Workshop: Non-Academic Careers for STS Scholars

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This workshop will be a pre-conference event at the 2017 Society for the Social Studies of Science (4S) meeting in Boston, MA. It will help prepare Science, Technology and Society (STS) graduate students to consider, apply and succeed in non-academic jobs. Traditionally, graduate students receive minimal mentoring for careers outside of academia and this workshop is designed to broaden the mentoring opportunities beyond the university environment. This workshop will expose students to alternative careers outside of tenure-track jobs. By providing skills and strategies to STS graduate students this workshop will help STS maximize its societal impact by expanding STS graduates pathways into work in industry, government and the nonprofit sector.

The one day workshop will provide STS graduate students and faculty the opportunity to interact and network with STS scholars that have successfully transitioned into non-Academic careers. It will feature a series of panels with speakers from government, industry, and non-profit sectors. The speakers will discuss non-academic resumes, interviewing, networking, job opportunities and the skill sets necessary to have successful non-academic careers. The workshop will address how STS scholars have made the transition to careers outside of academia, and have become competitive in industry, government and non-profit sectors. Workshop participants: graduates students, faculty and non-academics will have the opportunity to explore how the current STS curriculum supports/hinders non-academic careers and suggest strategies to improve training for non-academic careers. The workshop will cultivate an environment of shared learning among these three groups in order to develop a report that reflects on the current and future curriculum needs of STS scholars.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Science, Technology Studies (STS) graduate programs primarily train graduate students to work in academic jobs. Unfortunately, like many STEM fields, there are not enough academic jobs to match the supply of STS graduate students, nor does every STS graduate student want to become an academic. As a result, graduate students do not receive adequate training for careers outside of academia and STS scholars are not aware of the value placed on their expertise in other sectors. Thus, there is a critical need to introduce STS graduate students to careers outside of academia. In the absence of such intervention, there will continue to be far more STS graduates seeking academic positions than there are academic jobs. Not only does this disillusion STS graduate students and hurt the field, it is also prevents STS from having the maximum impact outside of academia.

              This grant funded two workshop on non-academic careers. The first one-day workshop was at MIT on August 29, 2017, a day before the 2017 4S conference (see Appendix A for agenda). The second was a half-day workshop at the National Academies of Science, Engineering and Medicines on March 24th during the ST Global conference (see Appendix B for agenda). The workshops were structured in similar ways with a panel of professionals that had matriculated from a STS (or closely related programs). The professionals worked in government, non-profit and private sectors and offered brief opening statements before the floor was opened to questions from the audience. The second part of the workshops focused on skills building and preparing non-academic job applications and those sessions were led by professional career counselors from MIT and Virginia Tech, respectively. The second portion offered an opportunity to gain advice from a professional on writing resumes, interviewing and negotiating. During the workshop, the project team divided roles between facilitating and notetaking.

This workshop has intellectual merit to the field in two main ways. First, speakers and panelists at the workshop offered narratives about career diversity, how they unfold over time and skills they use. This information broadens the field’s understanding of education outcomes and the aspects of the degree that are most relevant to non-academic scientists. A second intellectual contribution of the workshop is that by creating a space for reflexive learning, we can diversify and increase the stock of STS knowledge. The non-academic participants shared fresh ideas about what is happening outside academia and those insights generated new research paths for STS scholars.

We foresee that this workshop will have many broad impacts for the STEM workforce and for the community at large. The workshop trained future STS scholars and open an array of career opportunities for them. By showcasing a range of STS careers, it is more likely that a diverse population of prospective students will enroll and graduate from STS programs. This is especially relevant because so many marginalized communities are not represented in graduate education, and although we do not know exact demographic distributions of STS degree programs, based on our own experience in the field, we see a lack of diversity in STS. We believe that exposing students to alternative STS careers will give them better perspective on future paths, relieve some of the disillusionment among PhD students, attract a wider range of scholars to the field and help STS maximize its societal impact by facilitating more STS graduates to work in industry, government and the nonprofit sector.
